Adds resource type classes

A set of resource types is added in /nova/resources/types.py. Simple
integer-based resources like CPU, RAM, and LocalDisk are included, in
addition to complex resources like NUMATopology, which uses the
primitives in nova.virt.hardware in order to update usage amounts and

would fit in the NUMA cells advertised and used on a compute node.

A base nova.resources.types.ResourceType class is used as a generic
class interface for any resource, simple or complex, to create
nova.resources.amounts.AmountSpec and UsageSpec objects that can be used
to represent concrete amount and usage records. The idea here is to have
a single way of modeling some resource that is provided by a compute
node, and a single way of comparing a requested amount of something with
the capacity and usage records of the provider of that resource.

The next patch in the series adds methods to nova.objects.ComputeNode
that allow its resources (RAM, CPU, LocalDisk, PCI devices, NUMA cells,
etc) to be queried as nova.resource.amounts.UsageSpec objects.

Partially-implements: resource-objects

subject: Add object models for comparing resource amounts
commit_message:
Add object models for comparing resource amounts

Right now, we have 4 distinct ways (!) of comparing resources in the
resource tracker:

- Straight integer amounts stored in top-level key/value pairs in the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.old_resources dictionary
  attribute. For example: {"local_gb": X, "local_gb_used": Y}

- NUMA topology amounts and usages are stored as a serialized
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology/VirtNUMAHostTopology
  pair in the old_resources dictionary under the 'numa_topology' key:
  {"numa_topology": JSON-BLOB}

- PCI device amounts and usages are separately tracked by the
  nova.compute.resource_tracker.ResourceTracker.pci_tracker object. This
  really is quite silly, and duplicates a ton of comparison functionality
  from both NUMA and the standard integer amount/usage stuff. The results
  of this pci_tracker work is placed into the "pci_devices" and
  "pci_passthrough_devices" (no idea why it was necessary to have two keys
  here...) as a JSON-serialized BLOB of information that comes directly from
  the pci_stats field in the compute_nodes table.

- The "extensible resource tracker" places "stuff" into a "stats" key in
  the top-level old_resources dictionary attribute. The "stuff" is a
  collection of free-form, unstructured, and undocumented amount
  information for whatever resource classes happen to be included by the
  deployer.

Just like we have 4 distinct ways of comparing resource amounts, we have
four totally different ways of comparing capacity of a resource with the
used amount of that resource:

- Straight integer amounts are compared using a simple `(total - used) >
  requested` formula.

- NUMA topology usage records use a set of classes that derive from
  nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMATopology that enable different usage and cell
  topologies to be compared for fit. Unfortunately, the
  VirtNUMAHostTopology object inherited the nova.compute.claim.Claim
  object's claim_test() method, which tightly couples the (supposedly
  non-coupled) nova.virt.hardware classes to the Claim interface in the
  resource tracker.

- PCI device resource usages are managed in yet another completely
  different way, using the code in nova.pci.pci_manager.PciManager, which
  is a member of the resource tracker's pci_tracker attribute.

- And still yet the extensible resource tracker plugins offer another way
  of calculating and storing usage records: in a JSON blob that is passed
  from one plugin to another, which the plugin expected to update the
  supplied dictionary with a usage record that only it understands.

This patch adds the basic object models that will enable us to have a
single interface for comparing resource amounts and usages. It adds some
helper classes in /nova/resources/amounts.py that allow any "amount" of
a resource to be specified using the same generalized class, and any
capacity/usage of any resource to be both updated and check for
available room for a requested amount of some resource -- again, all in
a consistent generalized class interface.

The next patch in the series adds the actual resource types that
utilize the AmountSpec and UsageSpec objects introduced in this patch.

Change-Id: I6676fe3a9fb7d23adae1819cebab3a8cbad7487e
Partially-implements: resource-objects

subject: Reduced lvm metadata size to (actual size - 8M)
commit_message:
Reduced lvm metadata size to (actual size - 8M)

The reason for that is to make sure that
there will be enough space for creating logical volumes.
Default lvm extension size is 4M. Nailgun volume
manager does not care of it and if physical volume size
is 4M * N + 3M and lvm metadata size is 4M * L then only
4M * (N-L) + 3M of space will be available for
creating logical extensions. So only 4M * (N-L) of space
will be available for logical volumes, while nailgun
volume manager might reguire 4M * (N-L) + 3M
logical volume. Besides, parted aligns partitions
according to its own algorithm and actual partition might
be a bit smaller than integer number of mebibytes.

Implements: blueprint image-based-provisioning
Change-Id: I14e5e8e37a52685a67a99fece630b368e6064c76

subject: Fix possible race condition for accept transfer
commit_message:
Fix possible race condition for accept transfer

Accept transfer API workflow is currently like this:

  call volume_api.accept_transfer()
    |
    --- RPC cast to volume manager
          |
          --- volume manager calls volume driver accept_transfer()

  update volume's DB record

Given the non-blocking nature of RPC cast, what happens in volume
manager and volume driver can happen in parallel with the DB update.
If volume driver relies on original DB record to do things, then
DB record shouldn't be updated until volume driver finishes its job.

So this patch change volume RPC API accept_transfer() from cast
to call to make sure the workflow is in serialized manner.  Also
elevated the context when volume manager tries to update the DB
record when driver has done accept_transfer().

Closes-bug: #1357432

Conflicts:
    cinder/volume/rpcapi.py

Change-Id: Ieae52e167aa02967338e0be5d78d570d682faa7a

subject: Fix KeyError in dhcp_rpc when plugin.port_update raise exception
commit_message:
Fix KeyError in dhcp_rpc when plugin.port_update raise exception

KeyError exception is seen because of following reasons

* DhcpRpcCallback._port_action() is called by two functions
   -  DhcpRpcCallback.create_dchp_port()
   -  DhcpRpcCallback.update_dhcp_port()

* When create_dhcp_port() function calls _port_action(), the
  function argument 'port' will have the body as
  {'port': {'network_id': foo_network_id, 'fixed_ips': [..] ...}

* When update_dhcp_port() function calls _port_action(), the
  function argument 'port' will have the body as
  {'id': port_id, 'port': {{'port': {'network_id': foo_network_id,
			            'fixed_ips': [..] ...}}

* If an exception occurs when _port_action() calls plugin.create_port(),
  network id is accessed as
  net_id = port['port']['network_id']

* If an exception occurs when _port_action() calls plugin.update_port(),
  network id is accessed as
  net_id = port['port']['network_id']
  which is causing the KeyError. network_id should have been accessed as
  net_id = port['port']['port']['network_id']

This patch fixes the issue by making the _port_action() take the
same port body. update_dhcp_port() insteading of passing the port_id
and port information in a single argument, it now adds port_id
in the port body itself.

Change-Id: I70b92fa20b421b05ca2053a9a57f62db726f7625
Closes-bug: #1378508

subject: Make proxy compute object etag if not sent by client
commit_message:
Make proxy compute object etag if not sent by client

Currently, if a client makes a PUT request and does not send the Etag
header, each object server computes the Etag individually. If there is
data corruption between the proxy and an object server, Swift can end
up with two good copies and one corrupt copy of the object, but both
having the same timestamp. Neither replication nor auditing cleans
this up.

This commit makes the proxy compute the md5 of the object and send it
in a footer *after* the object has been sent to the backends. This is
all in the same request, not two separate ones. The object server
checks it and rejects the PUT if the proxy-sent etag doesn't match the
computed one, just like with the client-supplied etag.

The proxy only does this if the client didn't send an etag. If the
client did send one, everything continues working like it does today.

Bonus fix: make the proxy send etags (in the headers, not a footer)
for object COPY requests, not including SLO and DLO.

The wire format is a multipart MIME document. For sanity during a
rolling upgrade, the multipart MIME document is only sent to the
object server if it indicates, via 100 Continue header, that it knows
how to consume it.

Example 1 (new proxy, new obj server):

   proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
          X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

     obj: 100 Continue
        X-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

   proxy: --MIMEmimeMIMEmime...

Example2: (new proxy, old obj server)

   proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
          X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

     obj: 100 Continue

   proxy: <obj body>

This is also beneficial for EC work, as it provides a general
mechanism for sending header values *after* the request body. EC will
need this to store the object's original Etag if the client doesn't
send it since the object servers won't be able to compute it.

Change-Id: I347d98f8a732da510d6ab17b95130a5b6f0a8d76

subject: libvirt: Make sure volumes are well detected during block migration
commit_message:
libvirt: Make sure volumes are well detected during block migration

Current implementation of live migration in libvirt incorrectly includes
block devices on shared storage (e.g., NFS) when computing destination
storage requirements. Since these volumes are already on shared storage
they do not need to be migrated. As a result, migration fails if the
amount of free space on the shared drive is less than the size of the
volume to be migrated. The problem is addressed by adding a
block_device_info parameter to check_can_live_migrate_source() to allow
volumes to be filtered correctly when computing migration space
requirements.

This only fixes the issue on libvirt: it is unclear whether other
implementations suffer from the same issue.

Thanks to Florent Flament for spotting and fixing an issue while trying out
this patch.

Co-Authored-By: Florent Flament <florent.flament@cloudwatt.com>

subject: Fix image metadata returned for volumes
commit_message:
Fix image metadata returned for volumes

When creating a volume from a glance image, cinder stores the original
image metadata in volume_glance_metadata. This is a key/value store,
and all the values are strings.

When Nova boots an instance from a volume, it passes the image
metadata returned by cinder, which is all strings. If a driver
expects these values to be ints, as they are when booting from an
image, it will get a type error.

This change also pulls size from the volume directly rather than
taking the value from the stored image metadata. This is because the
volume will have been created in 1Gb increments, and is unlikely to be
the same size as the original image. It may also have been
subsequently extended.

subject: Fix cleanup for EC2 test_compute_with_volumes

Volume cleanup for test_compute_with_volumes fails when volume is in
"error" state.

cleanup part destroy_volume_wait() is to delete the volume and detach
before delete if necessary.
In destroy_volume_wait(), before detaching the volume there is checks if
volume status is not "available" but that is not sufficient enough to
guarantee that volume is attached. Volume status can be "error".

state then, detach request will through the error as mentioned in
bug# 1310896.

Logic in destroy_volume_wait should be checking of state as "in-use" before
trying to detach volume. So that if it is in "in-use" state then detach and
go for volume delete. If not in "in-use" ("available" or  "error" etc) then

subject: Export cinder volumes only if the status is 'in-use'
commit_message:
Export cinder volumes only if the status is 'in-use'

Currently, cinder volumes are exported both 'in-use' and 'available'
after restarting cinder-volume service.
This behavior was introduced following commit.

  commit ffefe18334a9456250e1b6ff88b7b47fb366f374
  Author: Zhiteng Huang <zhithuang@ebaysf.com>
  Date: Sat Aug 23 18:32:57 2014 +0000

If the volumes are attached to nova instances, they should be exported
via tgtd after restarting cinder-volume.
But the volumes which are not attached to instances must not be exported
because everyone can connect these volumes.

This patch changes volume export behavior that exports a volume only if
the volume status is 'in-use'.

commit_message:
Ignore errors when deleting non-existing vifs

if the network-vif-plugged event doesn't arrive in time) a
subsequent delete will also fail when it tries to delete the
vif, leaving the instance in a Error(deleting) state.

This can be avoided by including the "--if-exists" option to
the ovs-vsctl command so that the command doesn't fail if the
vif doesn't exist.
